content.body: I think I'm leaning strong into the "not worth trying, just stick to an ident" camp, because :: is meant to be "like ., but the obj and function don't have to be previously related", and the more we move away from that the more confusing it'll get.

content.body: The issue suggests that a :: get/set is treated differently from a call. So the get/set logic comes from the lhs using the rhs as a param
content.formatted_body: The issue suggests that a :: get/set is treated differently from a call. So the get/set logic comes from the lhs using the rhs as a param

content.body: Yes, wrong way round.
We just don't have a way to *declare* that something is a "getter fn", so the RHS would have to, like, use a Symbol to declare it's usable as a bind-getter or bind-setter
content.formatted_body: We just don't have a way to declare that something is a "getter fn", so the RHS would have to, like, use a Symbol to declare it's usable as a bind-getter or bind-setter

content.body: `class Ephemeron extends WeakMap { [Symbol.bindGet]() { ...} }`
content.formatted_body: class Ephemeron extends WeakMap { [Symbol.bindGet]() { ...} }

content.body: the point of weakmaps as ephemerons is letting you attach "properties" to objects in ways that the objects (or anyone else) can't observe on their own
* `class Ephemeron extends WeakMap { [Symbol.bindGet]() { ...} }`
content.formatted_body: * class Ephemeron extends WeakMap { [Symbol.bindGet]() { ...} }

So `a.b` is call [[get]] on deref(a) with toStringOrSymbol(deref(b)).
and
`a::b` is call Symbol.bindGet on deref(a) with the value of deref(b).

content.body: or, well, i'm unclear on exactly the mechanics you're implying by that second one. i wrote up a possible code example in https://github.com/js-choi/proposal-bind-this/issues/17#issuecomment-946005508
okay, reading more closely, yeah, you've still got it backwards
the bindGet has to live on b, and be called with a
same as the "bindCall" lives on b and is called with a in `a::b()`
content.formatted_body: same as the "bindCall" lives on b and is called with a in a::b()

content.body: ("bindCall" just being the unforgable version of `b.call()`)
content.formatted_body: ("bindCall" just being the unforgable version of b.call())

content.body: basically if, instead of thinking of `a::b()` as "call `b()` with `a` bound to its `this`)" you think of it as "call `b.call()` with `a` as its first argument", then `a::b` is exactly the same with `b[Symbol.bindGet]` and `b[Symbol.bindSet]`
content.formatted_body: basically if, instead of thinking of a::b() as "call b() with a bound to its this)" you think of it as "call b.call() with a as its first argument", then a::b is exactly the same with b[Symbol.bindGet] and b[Symbol.bindSet]

content.body: My mind has clicked into place now thanks!

* basically if, instead of thinking of `a::b()` as "call `b()` with `a` bound to its `this`)" you think of it as "call `b.call()` with `a` as its first argument", then `a::b` is exactly the same with `b[Symbol.bindGet]()` and `b[Symbol.bindSet]()`
content.formatted_body: * basically if, instead of thinking of a::b() as "call b() with a bound to its this)" you think of it as "call b.call() with a as its first argument", then a::b is exactly the same with b[Symbol.bindGet]() and b[Symbol.bindSet]()

content.body: Yeah, the metaprogramming aspect is incidental here, it's just required to get it to work since we have an *intrinsic* notion of an object being callable, but "invokable as a getter" is extrinsic in today's JS (based on how a function is attached to an object).
content.formatted_body: Yeah, the metaprogramming aspect is incidental here, it's just required to get it to work since we have an intrinsic notion of an object being callable, but "invokable as a getter" is extrinsic in today's JS (based on how a function is attached to an object).

content.body: Wait, isn't `a::b()` a temporary method on `a`?
content.formatted_body: Wait, isn't a::b() a temporary method on a?

content.body: it's not an unreasonable way to think about it, so that's understandable
"temporary" = "not actually there"
it's "a temporary method" *semantically*. Technically it's "unforgably call `b.call(a, ...)`", which has nothing to do with methods.
content.formatted_body: it's "a temporary method" semantically. Technically it's "unforgably call b.call(a, ...)", which has nothing to do with methods.
